title: Hinsdale District 86 considers merging Central, South The Doings Weekly
text:
The Hinsdale High School District 86 Board has been reviewing recommendations for improvements to the district's facilities and programs, such as a new swimming pool at Hinsdale Central and a new cafeteria at Hinsdale South.
Now the school board is broadening its view of possible changes to include who will attend each school.
Board members are considering putting an advisory referendum on the March ballot asking Hinsdale South and Hinsdale Central should be reorganized so that freshmen and sophomores attend one school and juniors and seniors attend the other.
Lyons Township High School is divided that way, with freshmen and sophomores attending the south campus at 49th Street and Willow Springs Road in Western Springs, and juniors and seniors attending the north campus at 100 S. Brainard Ave. in La Grange.
"We have a population imbalance at our two schools," said board member Jennifer Planson, who proposed the idea..
About 2,850 students attend Hinsdale Central High School this fall, compared with about 1,620 at Hinsdale South.
Hinsdale Central also is more crowded than South, a fact that has led a Steering Committee to recommend 20 more teaching spaces, such as classrooms, labs and study halls, be added at Central.
Before the district starts expanding and remodeling schools, the district should consider whether students could be reassigned to balance the student population, Planson said. Hinsdale South would have to expand if it were to hold roughly half the total district enrollment, officials said.

(Kimberly Fornek) Although she suggested the idea of a freshman/sophomore campus and a junior/senior campus, Planson said she does not know whether that would be the best course.
"I'm neither for it, nor against it," Planson said Friday. "Now is the time to have the conversation. We are in the early stages of our master facilities plan."
Jessica Hurt, the chairman of Hinsdale Central's social studies department, says she is familiar with the structure of dividing schools by grade level because her husband teaches at LTHS.
She believes one drawback is, "school spirit gets lost. School spirit is driven by the upper class men; they are the leaders of the clubs and the sports teams."
She also wonders whether it would limit the choice of classes for students.
Currently, District 86 allows any level student to take any class for which he qualifies. In some classes, like American politics, freshmen, sophomores, juniors and seniors all may be in the same class.

(Kimberly Fornek) Dividing the grades between two schools would affect the sequencing of classes students take, if some classes are not going to be available to them in the upper grades, Hurt said.
On the other hand, if reorganizing the two schools reduces class size, Hurt said she is in favor of it.
"We have very large classes (at Central). I have 29 students in a world cultures class," Hurt said. "If it helped with space and class size, that would be great."
Volunteers on more than a dozen functional teams during the spring and summer identified areas they think need to be improved at all the district's facilities and grounds. The estimated cost of many of the items is in the tens of millions, leading people to consider the possibility that a referendum for a tax increase may be in the district's future.
Because Hinsdale Central is the older school and the one with more students, more improvements were recommended for Central than for South.
But the families who live in South's attendance boundaries make up a significant number of voters, school board member Claudia Manley said. Voters are not likely to agree to pay more money if the school their children or grandchildren attend would not benefit, Manley said.
Dividing students up according to grade, instead of geographic boundaries, would mean each student would attend both schools if they stayed in District 86 for four years.
Board President Kay Gallo and members Kathleen Hirsman and Edward Corcoran also were in favor of putting an advisory referendum on the March ballot.
Corcoran also suggested Westmont High School should consider merging with District 86, because the school is small. Enrollment was about 450 students this fall. Westmont High School is part of Community Unit School District 201, which includes two elementary schools and a junior high school, in addition to the high school.
Corcoran said he is against any boundary changes within District 86, but believes a merger with Westmont High School would provide more opportunities for the Westmont students and be a more efficient use of resources.
The District 86 Superintendent Bruce Law was asked to check with the district's lawyers and District 201 officials to see if a merger is possible.
Hirsman said assigning students to Central or South by grade level might be a less drastic change than revising the geographic boundaries for the school or the district.
